It may be better with a meat filling, but the vegetarian option was a bit lackluster. 

Overall this place was a nice stop and I would definitely go back for their pho!
author: Jimmy C.

description: hit or miss, popular fast moving line.  say banh mi, and they stare at you blankly.  sandwich -- ah ha.  the lemongrass pork was a little chewy, and the sandwich sloppily constructed.  suffices as a quick bite.
author: Rob C.

description: I'm a huge fan of properly picked veggies! I loved my salad bowl with lemongrass pork, so satisfying but not too heavy. The flavors are so plentiful that I barely use the dressings offered.
author: Briget P.

description:
I stopped by on a lunch break while working the Fancy Food Show. The setup is very similar to Chipotle with sandwich, bowl, spring roll, or pho (only available after 3pm) options.

I got two bowls and two sandwiches (1 pork and 1 chicken of each) and got a little bit of every vegetable for the bowl. My items were lined up as so on the assembly line: bowl, bowl, sandwich, sandwich. As one girl finished my first bowl, another girl asked the man next to me what veggies he wanted on his bowl. Then she started filling up MY bowl with what the guy wanted. I had to stop her as she was putting a plethora of cilantro (as requested by the man) in my bowl. He and I agreed to switch bowls since he also ordered the pork in his. The staff really needs to communicate when it comes to filling the orders.

When I checked out, the cashier fumbled to put my items together in a bag. Was it their first time filling a somewhat large order? 

I left and got back to the show to eat my lunch only to find that my bowl had brown rice :( I requested for white rice, but remember when that guy and I had to switch bowls? Sad.. Brown rice has higher levels of arsenic than that of white rice so I try to stay away from it.

My bowl was mostly salad with lots of veggies and I had to dig to find the meat and rice. I was also not impressed with the .10 charge for a bag. I get that I'm in SF and there is a charge for a bag at grocery stores and retail clothing stores, but for takeout lunch? At least tell me there is a charge so I can be environmentally friendly and opt for no bag.
author: Nitar L.

description: This is one of my favorite eatery joints near my workplace. The fresh rolls and bahmi are my favorites. service of orders is always fast and moving. Quality of the food has not changed, its stays as delicious and fresh as it was the first time. Highly recommend it!
author: Manmeet G.

description:
Pretty good Vietnamese spring rolls. I was a bit cautious since Yelp had told me that they didn't receive a satisfactory cleanliness rating. There are a lot of fast-casual Chipotle-style ordeals in the area, but I like this one in particular because I love the sauces, combinations, and results. The meal is still light, but I never leave hungry for more. For vegetarian friends, this is a great option too!

My only complaints is that it's quite pricey for spring rolls, which are extremely cheap to make at-home or get at a pho restaurant for $5. Also, the tables get really dirty during the lunch rush.
author: Jessica L.

description:
Very convenient, but meat portion not so generous. I didn't really get filled off of three rolls. Standard is a pretty good combo of mixings, otherwise you can only choose 5 toppings for the create your own rolls options. I did like the taro chips! There are a couple outlets in case you need charging. Sauces available, two allowed per three spring rolls ordered. I particularly liked the ginger carrot carrot sauce...yum!

Would be back if I craved some create my own spring rolls, but obviously not for authentic Vietnamese spring rolls.
author: Anna S.

description: I was disappointed today. I ate here several times before but  today's rolls were bad. Full of leaves and greens, very little meat and not much flavor. I did not order vegan rolls. I ordered rolls with chicken, pork, and shrimp. Most of the roll was leaves and it tasted like grass.
author: Andy D.

description: This place is what I would imagine to be the product of a millennial asking their Asian parents to open up a restaurant. It's a cleaned up, toned down Vietnamese fast food place for working people out to get a healthy power lunch. And surprisingly, the concept works. The ingredients are fresh, less greasy but still tasty. This may be the next craze in the fast food chipotle-like chain.
author: O K.

description: Love, love, love Freshroll! I take my daughter there for lunch whenever we come to visit San Francisco! I wish we had one in San Diego. :-( The sandwich and rolls are amazing! I love that you can pick and choose your ingredients, although I only choose the protein and then get everything else "standard" because it's so delicious. I love how light and healthy everything feels. Highly recommend!
author: Lee Anne G.

description: I order Pho with rare beef. The Pho soup is very tasty. I drink all of it. The basil and spring sprout are fresh. Beef is nice too.
author: Andy Juzheng Z.

description:
There's not much not to like about Freshroll - great concept, tasty food and dipping sauces and quick and friendly service. Missing a star because they don't serve pho during lunch. What?!

The concept of made to order fresh rolls is neat or if you choose to have a noodle bowl or banh mi to order. Choice of a few fillings - tofu, pork and beef - and choices of traditional/standard veggies and some less traditional like avocados (guess we are in California) make for great finished product. While I was ordering my rolls, I felt like I was at a taqueria crafting my perfect meat and veggie mixture (rice paper) wraps. 

I quite enjoyed my traditional pork and beef rolls. I opted for the spicy chili sauce and peanut sauce and because I love sriracha I put slather a healthy squeeze in the peanut sauce. I'm a fan. Meats - tasty and grilled well. Veggies - standardly fresh when expected to be fresh and pickled just right when expected to be picked. 

Another time I ordered the noodle bowl (but really wanted pho), they offered a small side of the pho broth and I made the bowl a pseudo bowl of pho back at the office. Nice that they offered a compromise, but was definitely lacking and not so cohesive. Will have to try their pho another time.

Freshroll has made my lunch rotation...and I can even save one roll for a snack esp if I wanna make a quick bee line to Sharetea at the Metreon.
author: Marie B.

description:
I've only gotten the salads here and every time I left sated and happy. Its a good lunch option for the area. A good value given the quality and quantity. 

I've gotten the pork and the chicken and while the pork was surprisingly good I think I favor the chicken. One of them is lemongrass flavored (the pork I think) and unfortunately it's not very lemongrass-y. It's still tasty though. 

Try the salad with all the trimmings. Get a few of the sauces. You might not be overjoyed, but you won't walk away regretting it.
author: Boris K.

description:
Honestly, I love(d) this place -the staff is friendly, it fills me up, feels healthy, I get some veggies in at lunch, BUT what the holy heck is up with the 68 Health Score?  Bottom 5% in the neighborhood?  I'm not a germ-a-phobe. I believe in the 5-second rule, I don't care if you double dip, I like my steaks and burgers rare, but a 68 health score is icky. 

Now, I'm super bummed, this was totally my lunch plan for today and now it's 2:30 and now I'm HUNGRY and without a plan. WahWah.
author: Laura M.

description: The rolls are all lettuce and no taste.  One visit is not enough to make a final decision, but I certainly won't get the rolls when I return.  I suggest the Noodles place just a couple of doors down the road.
author: Frank B.

description:
Will not be returning. The whole experience was terrible. 

Pho:
The broth was lacking in flavor, beef was tough, way to many onions, and the basil was just tossed in whole stem and all. Literally the worst I've ever had. 

Spring roll:
Decent actually only reason the place got an extra star from me. Still over priced though. 

Environment:
LOUD!!! Pop music playing the whole time. Felt like I was at a night club. Seating is limited and you will be sitting next to or across from a stranger. 

Price:
Maybe good for San Fran but $10 for the spring rolls and $10 for pho not my idea of a bargain. If the pho was good sure might be worth it but at $10 I will never be returning.
author: Chris R.

description:
The restaurants around the Metreon are so unique and their concepts are way too cool. Who would have thought you can turn any cuisine into a Chipotle style one? 

I ordered the lemongrass pork bowl ($7.95) with extra pickled veggies and everything except for jalapenos and peppers. The second best part is picking from their assortment of dipping sauces. My favorite include: fish sauce (vietnamese vinaigrette dressing), peanut sauce, and citrus ginger. Be careful not to drench your bowl in the sauces (I found it best to dip it). The pineapple slices are also a nice refreshing taste especially after loading up on my fish sauce. Super sweet!

The only thing that was annoying was getting started. The meat is layered second from the bottom so you have to dig. LOVE the option for brown rice if you're watching your starch intake.
author: Lauren K.

description:
I'm personally not a huge fan of lunch as a meal.

I mean, part of me wants to get out of the office and treat myself to actual food. Not the frozen lasagna that I brought from home. But most of the time I end up staying at my desk noshing slowly while responding to the influx of emails from the morning. 

For the days where I allow myself the freedom of picking a place to eat, I forget that almost everybody else has the same idea as I and I end up spending half my lunch in line. Don't let the line here daunt you. It was 50~ people deep when I got there yet I got my 3 customized rolls with enough time to stroll over to Yerba Buena and enjoy them there.

The spring rolls themselves are big and yes, fresh. Pick a protein and sauce that you like because those are the flavors that will dominate. Maybe a little overpriced (8.50 for 3) but again you're paying for the convenience. Their taro chips are a fun side to get. If you really want something fast, grab something from their pre-made section and skidaddle to avoid the manic FiDi workers.

Thanks for making lunch easy, Freshroll :)
author: Jenny Q.

description:
Kinda pricey for 3 rolls made fresh to order.
It's a nice concept but it can take a while If there's a line. 

You pick your protein and veg and the sauces are self serve.  I ordered half lemongrass pork and garlic shrimp. I ordered their standard set of vegetables. 

The rolls were sloppy and didn't have even distribution of ingredients. The picked veg was too sour in my opinion. And the shrimp were tiny. There was barely any meat. 

Three rolls for close to $11
author: Heejin L.

description: I used to love this place, but they have taken so many cost cutting measures that I won't be back.  They guard the sauces like it is in short supply.  They limit you to two small packets of sauce.  So unless you like eating dry tofu and rice, I would not recommend it.  I understand the need to control expenses, but realistically how much does the sauce cost?
author: G K.

description:
This place is great if you want to go for a quick vietnamese bite. The food is super fresh and super tasty! 

Also, if you have paypal check their promotion ($10 off first purchase!)
author: Nuno S.

description:
I've been here a few times already and I've tried the lemongrass pork and chicken vermicelli which come with a lot of toppings such as jalapeños, cut up carrots, and other light vegetables that add some texture and flavour to the meals. Sometimes the noodles seem to come from frozen because they're hard and brittle. But the protein are usually freshly cooked, juicy and delicious. I'm familiar with vietnamese food as I've had a bunch of it when I was in Toronto and it's average for what I've had here. But if you're trying vietnamese for your first time, this place is a great place to visit.

Good portions that fill you up! Downside is the line during lunch is quite long and often takes 10 - 15 minutes from lining up to walking out the door with your meal.
author: Christopher L.

description: Very fresh, healthy and tasty
author: Namrata J.

description:
Interesting concept of BYO Vietnamese spring rolls, but way too overpriced for what it actually is. 

The service was slow, and the person making my rolls was being stingy with all the toppings. She practically put 5 pieces of noodles and a handful of veggies that don't normally belong in there.

The way they were rolled was beyond sloppy. Even I can roll better, and I'm not even Vietnamese (but my MIL is) !

$8+ for 3 spring rolls. If you're okay with not having authentic spring rolls, and need something light to snack on, then this is the place. There aren't many options in the Metreon, so this is one of the better choices.
author: Ivana Y.

description:
The 2 times I've gone, I've gotten attitude from the person serving me. So right off the bat, we're not off to a good start. The food itself is nowhere near authentic Vietnamese food. The vermicelli was undercooked and they give you very small portions of meat. There are some interesting "fusion" elements like jalapenos and pineapple. The pineapple by itself tastes quite good. Altogether the chicken vermicelli bowl tasted really bad together and totally did not satisfy my vietnamese vermicelli craving. 

The next time I went, I figured I would try the rice bowl, but the rice was either undercooked or left out too long and was very hard. Once again very small portions of the pork. The pork was extremely salty and tough, not even well cooked. I suppose I could go again to try the apparently amazing banh mi...but given my past experiences I would not return.
author: Alfonso C.

description:
I want to like this place but it's a little too whitewashed for me. I like the concept, Vietnamese fast food with a little modern twist. The prices reflect the "modernization" but honestly, it doesn't make the dishes better than the traditional recipes, they just charge you more and it's a little bit off. Just no regard for flavor profiles and ingredient combinations. Call me a snob, but you don't throw completely random ingredients into a pot and then call it gumbo because you shook a little of Emeril's spice mix in it and said BAM! Plus, how ya gonna advertise the crispy stick inside the roll but then tell me afterwards that it's an up-charge and you can't add it. I mean lame. Biggest offense though is that the rolls aren't rolled tightly like they should be, that's the red flag for Viet quality standards. 

I've had worse, for sure. But I wouldn't come back here. There's too many other super deRish places to eat in SF.
author: Liz T.

description: It's ok. I got two garlic shrimp spring rolls for lunch. Told them no noodles so they loaded it with veggies. The shrimp were small and overcooked. Think of it as the Qdoba of Vietnamese food. Healthier than a burger but not the best thing ever. They also have a sandwich, chicken pho and bowls (noodle, tice or brown rice). Across from Moscone Center so convenient.
author: Linda G.

description:
It's...OK. 

I've passed by Freshroll countless times, as I have been to Moscone for an annual work conference several years in a row. The freshrolls are huge (they better be for $9), and tasty, although I was taken back by the abundance of dried crunchy onions. I did not get to try the banh mi, although my coworker did and he enjoyed it. Personally, I think $7 for a banh mi is a crime, so I don't think I'll ever try it, lol.
author: Ho L.

description:
If there's a negative option, I'll highly -5 stars on this place.
My buddy & I went to this place to grab our dinner, pretty bad sandwich (it should be called banh mi instead). That night I had a really bad food poisoning and had to run to the toilet 4 times. Checked with my buddy in the morning and he did get the food poisoning too. This place is DIRTY. 

Big time garbage
author: Melvin C.

description:
Was craving fresh spring rolls and stopped by this place for a quick lunch. 
They make it right on the spot and you can mix tofu, chicken, pork, etc. 
Taste is mediocre, but the price is high. 
Apparently, it is better to get their pho rather than their rolls.
author: Brenda Jiwon L.

description:
Popular place for lunch, especially for conference goers, for this particular location.

It's basically Vietnamese Chipotle. I like it quite a bit better than Asian Box because it actually has interesting options - rolls or vermicelli or rice bowls -- and it focuses entirely on one type of Asian cuisine. There is pho as well but only after 3pm on weekdays, so I didn't get to try it.

The rice bowl I got was solid, and they have extra sauce at the condiments bar so you can actually try all their sauces without opting in to any one of them. If you get the rolls, you might need to order something extra -- because it's not so filling. Or just get a roll as a side to the other mains. However, the taro chips were meh. I wouldn't recommend getting it.

Definitely beats some of the other fast food nearby.
author: Alice C.

description:
Went here because I wanted something that was light and fast. I will admit I think the prices are high, but I guess I am in San Francisco in the Union Square area and not back home in the Garden Grove area. 

So here you can either do the fresh rolls, banh mi (sandwich), rice/noodle bowl, salad bowl, or a pho bowl. Today, I decided to get the fresh rolls while my friend went with the banh mi. 

For $8, I will admit that I was expecting these rolls either to blow my mind or be freaking huge. So you get three rolls and you can either get all the same type of protein or you can mix it up and have all three of them different if you wanted. I chose to have 2 pork and 1 chicken. I felt they were being pretty stingy with all the ingredients. I mean noodles cost nothing and they put only a pinch of noodles for each roll. But if I ignore the cost and the dinky portions (in my opinion), the rolls were tasty. I liked the both the lemongrass pork and chicken (tasted like teriyaki). The sauces they have are all good too.

My friend said the banh mi was good. She got the pork as well. Oh, she had the lychee tea and said that it was not too sweet and refreshing
author: Kristina L.

description:
Tablea do not seemed to be cleaned frequently.  Interior is nice and bright. Definitely would not try to bring a large group in here. 

Servings are a nice size and food is good.
author: ray a.

description:
Mixed review..Food was good, but the staff reminded me of college students working that didn't care. Employees had a sloppy  appearance and the place was not to sanitary. 
The bathroom had urine all over the floor and smelled really bad.
author: Kg H.

description:
Yum!! Love the sauce though I don't think the more traditional banh mi sandwiches are this saucy. The set up reminds me of Chipotle- walk through the line, add your fillings and sauces. Efficient. During peak time, it's not too fun to be sitting inside, but it's a perfect grab and go. Also the long table facing the windows was sticky... 

The grilled chicken banh mi is quite filling. Lots of tender chicken, lots of sauce. The pickled veggies are also really good. 

The location is very convenient, steps away from the Metreon and Marriott Marquis.
author: Neesh Q.

description: Hit the spot.  it was the right price for an early dinner or late afternoon snack when I was really craving something tasty and asian. Probably one of the best aspects about it is it's location, since it is so close to Moscone. I got the bond me with grilled chicken and it was very good. Not too many for oils or anything like that, just a really good sandwich with really fresh ingredients.
author: Andrew L.

description: Terrible excuse of a whitewashed vietnamese "fast food" place. It's chipotle style and does not work for pho. The rolls are okay but they make it really sloppy. No sauce. I'd rather go to any authentic restaurant than eat this garbage again. No idea how the reviews are so high.
author: Steph Y.

description:
Even though it's not exactly authentic - the rolls here are pretty tasty and more importantly among the few healthy options for fast food. The location is very convenient - right by the metreon/ target.

They don't seem to advertise this on yelp but on their side tv screen - they mention if you check in on yelp or fb - you can get 10% off your order - just show the cashier. 

Menu is pretty straight forward - you pick either rolls, rice bowl, bahn mi (sandwich), or pho. Then a protein - chicken, pork, tofu, shrimp (extra), beef (pho only). You can get the standard toppings (lettuce, cilantro, cucumber, bean sprouts, etc) or choose to custom it.

I stuck with the rolls, pork, the standard toppings, and the viet vinaigrette with sriracha. They have 3 other sauces - peanut sauce which was good, the sweet and sour chili which I thought was too sweet and thick, and the citrus ginger which was ok but the vinaigrette gives it a more authentic taste in my opinion. 

The rolls were good - the pork cooked well / not dry and the toppings were fresh. Prices are decent - with tax just under $10 for a meal. There's a good amount of seating and shared benches. A few seats outdoors as well. Overall a great option for healthy fast food.
author: Brenda L.

description: Simple. If you're going to prep food AND work the register, learn to change your gloves before going back to handling food! Disgusting. Hopefully no one gets sick! That includes the 5 people in line behind me. I would ask for a manager but I don't have time to make a scene today!
author: Jason A.

description: I had the salad w/ chicken, and the pork rolls. Both = DELICIOUS. I would 10/10 recommend and would definitely go back again. They are amazing portion sizes too.
author: Neda B.

description:
Three Vietnamese rolls, custom-made and fresh for under 10 bucks. Pick and choose from a variety of quality meats (the grilled chicken is really good!) and vegetables. Awesome sauces to top it off -- I'm a big fan of the peanut sauce. A filling meal that doesn't leave you feeling terrible or guilty. Which is really everything you wanted from a weekday lunch in downtown SF.

One (sort of) downside: The place is popular so the line is usually really long. But it moves fast enough that I didn't feel like I was waiting for too much time.

Also, note that the rolls are messier to eat than you might expect, so probably wise to grab a napkin and a fork.

Fast, cheap, delicious, and healthy. That's a winning combo that you don't see very often. Somehow Freshroll manages to hit them all -- impressive!
author: Brittany C.

description:
I walked by this place several times on my recent trip to SF. It was in between my hotel located in the financial district and all the shopping places we were going to in Union Square.  Every time I passed by I would walk in to look @ the menu.  I loved the concept: build it yourself  bowls, spring rolls, banh mi sandwiches, or pho. 

I finally had the opportunity to try it so one night when the family was eating our separate ways.  I decided to come in a pick up something and bring back to our hotel room for dinner.

I made a bowl with white rice as a base. You could also choose brown rice or vermicelli noodles. I was going to share with my toddler who loves rice so I chose this option along with the grilled chicken which he also likes. The other options were pork, shrimp, or tofu. I added pineapple, sliced cucumbers, romaine lettuce, pickled daikon/carrot/cilantro, and jalapenos on the side. Other options were avocado, bean sprouts, green onions.

It was exactly like the salad bowl I usually get @ Chipotle but with Vietnamese ingredients.

And the sauce I chose was the peanut sauce. There were many options but I don't remember what else they had.

I also got the house ice tea, a lightly sweetened lychee tea, which was very delicious!

And house made taro chips.

My meal was healthy, fresh, and delicious. I would eat it everyday if I could.

I'm not sure if they are a chain but hopefully they will make it to LA soon...
author: Christina W.

description:
Quantity to price ratio this is more a $$ than $ sign place but the quantity and pho we received was satisfactory for each person and we weren't left feeling hungry after. The only thing I found a little hard to manage was the spoon. It was so tiny! Anyway it's not the end of the world. I was still able to eat. 

We got the chicken and steak pho. The broth was tasty and filling. I'd like to come back and try other things.
author: Louisa D.

description:
This isn't where I'd go to get my Vietnamese fix; nevertheless, Freshroll is a good choice for a fresh and fairly healthy lunch. It's like a Vietnamese Chipotle, making ordering banh mi or bun thit nuong much more fun :)  They have a bunch of sauces you can choose from to soak your vermicelli in, or to dip your banh trang rolls in. I just go for the "Vietnamese Vinaigrette", which is essentially watered down fish sauce for the uncultured American.  The peanut sauce and the sweet & sour chili sauce (reminds me of a Thai sauce) are also decent.

Lines can get pretty long, especially when there's a conference across the street. But fear not, you can order ahead. Lastly, the people working here are generally pretty awesome. Even after dealing with hundreds of techies with name tags, they're still super upbeat and friendly.
author: Andrew D.

description: It's ok. Not great. Not bad. Just ok. Convenient. Quick and ready to go. Definitely alot of sales force people coming in here with the same grey and light blue backpack . Can i get one? It's cute.
author: Anna L.

description: Freshroll is what I go to when I want yummy without the food coma. It's a Chipotle-style, casual restaurant where you can pick what you want and sit down for a quick bite. Unlike other places near the Metreon, the prices aren't jacked up - the value is there! I love the garlic shrimp in the bowl or the roll! Lots of flavor and always feel good after leaving the joint :).
author: S. C.

description:
Quick and okay Vietnamese food. Had a fairly decent experience here and I've been dying to try this place ever since I started working in San Francisco. It was pretty busy around the 11:30am lunchtime. It's in a fantastic location, right near tons of office buildings, a couple of museums, and public transportation.
I got a bowl the other day with noodles, lemongrass pork, all toppings (lettuce, pickled veggies, bean sprouts, extra cilantro, cucumber, crispy shallots, and jalapeños), and the regular sauce that comes with the bowl. I didn't want all toppings but the ladies that were behind the counter didn't wait for my response after asking, they just piled everything on. I was fine with eating it still but I didn't really want a couple of things. I also asked for a side of what I thought was Sriracha mayo. I double checked with the cashier that it was sriracha mayo and he said yes but unfortunately it wasn't. It tasted more like a honey mustard or thousand island type of sweet orange sauce. So yeah totally unexpected. It tasted great on the lemongrass pork though but not the whole bowl itself. 
I would eat here again, it was quick and easy and overall didn't taste bad. It wasn't too expensive either, about 10 bucks. The service is just not too great, but the employees are generally nice. I feel like they get a little overwhelmed by how busy it gets. Hopefully my rating can go up a little the next time I come in though. I would definitely love to try the rolls next.
author: Cymone S.

description:
Helllllo Vietnamese Chipotle!  Discovered this little place through a PayPal deal (spend $10, get $10 back).  It was a pleasant afternoon in the neighborhood so it was nice to venture out to this area of the neighborhood near the Metreon.

You basically have four options:  Spring Rolls, Pho, Sandwich, or the Noodle Bowl.  I was starving so I went for the bowl with "the standard" (veggie) and garlic shrimp, which came out to be about $12.  I needed lots and lots of peanut butter sauce to mix with the noodles...otherwise it was just bland.

Not bad for $2, but definitely not worth it for $12.
author: Kevin C.

description:
I was downtown on my day off and decided to try this place since the bf's been a few times and he usually gets one of their banh mi sandwiches. Well, going against the grain, I opted to get 3 freshrolls. 

It was the peak of the lunchtime crowd and there was a long line, but it went by pretty quickly. Anyway, I chose 2 grilled chicken and 1 garlic shrimp with "The Standard," which includes lettuce, bean sprouts, cilantro, cucumbers, jalapeños, and pineapple. Then I added pickled veggies for free. Any other additions are free except for avocado, which is $1 more. 

I then proceeded to pay and I was asking what kind of flavor Izze drinks they had and the cashier just seemed very irritated and his coworker next to him was rude when she told me the drinks were actually behind me, which was my fault because I wasn't paying attention to the drinks when I walked in, but she didn't have to be rude. I was definitely expecting better customer service.

The grilled chicken rolls were good. The chicken was flavorful and everything was fresh. I especially loved the pineapple because it was sweet. The garlic shrimp roll was mediocre. You couldn't taste any garlic at all. I definitely won't be getting it next time. 

Overall, I think that this place has a cool concept. Like others have said, it's very reminiscent of a Vietnamese Chipotle in terms of choosing your protein and then what you want to go with it. The price on the other hand, is quite high, but that obviously comes with the location. I paid almost $12 for 3 freshrolls and a drink.
author: Fallon P.

description:
Fresh Roll (4.5): Vietnamese chipotle.  Fast. decent.  Would go again.

This place is essentially a Vietnamese chipotle.  You get in line and choose which "base" you want: sandwich, bowl, pho, etc.  You then choose which ingredients you want in case you don't want the usual stuff.

I got their standard lemongrass steak sandwich, which tasted pretty close to normal banh mi sandwiches us Vietnamese people love.  It's close -- not perfect -- but for the price, quality, and speed of the food preparation I would definitely recommend
author: Michael N.

description:
I ordered the freshrolls, which for about $9 isn't horrible, for their size.

I ordered three porks, and the meat was super dry. I grew up with Vietnamese food and can make my own, so these rolls, were kind of bland for me.

The carrot/daikon in it wasn't sour. The noodle were a little too wet. It would be better it there wasn't so much lettuce. I like lettuce but not to the point that it pops the roll.

The fish sauce that you can choose is good, but is it worth another visit?
author: Mei L.

description:
Really liked this place for being so simple and yummy for a quick lunch, fills up quick during lunch hours on the weekdays, but goes by pretty quickly. My friend found a hair in the rolls though, so kind of iffy on returning...
Aside from that, I (want to) like this place better than Asian Box under Macy's!
author: Heyun J.

description: Good portions and price. The pork was okay, not fantastic. The dad's tea was excellent, okay Vietnamese coffee.
author: Alison D.

description:
After a fun cocktail launch party in the Tenderloin, my girlfriend and I wanted to meet up with some friends for a light dinner at Freshroll.  I've walked by several times and never had the urge to go in, but I'm actually glad I did.

I'm a big fan of Vietnamese spring rolls, and get them all the time when I'm at a Vietnamese restaurant or in Oakland.  I went with two pork rolls and once chicken roll, with the works, all paired with their peanut dipping sauce.  I split the rolls with my girlfriend and didn't think it would be enough food.  Surprisingly, I actually got decently full from my half of the rolls and I thought they had great flavor.  The three-roll meal is about $8.50 and one roll is about $4.25, so definitely not the cheapest bite in the world, especially if you only get one roll.  However, the quality is great and they make it right in front of you, so you can be sure it's all fresh.

Service was fast and friendly and there's lots of seating in the dining area as well as outside.  I like that I can serve myself whatever sauces I like and get as much as I want.  It's conveniently located and has pet-friendly tables outside, and worth a second look for sure.

Food: 7/10

Service: 7/10

Price: $

Atmosphere: 7/10
author: Joe M.

description:
At lunch time, the line is usually at or out the door. For fun, I timed how long it would take to get from standing in line at the door to the service counter, and for 2 tries the answer is 20 minutes. By the time you've paid, there's usually a seat available inside (there are also a handful of seats outside).

The bowl is the way to go. You can get it all salad, all noodles/rice, or half and half. The lemongrass pork, grilled chicken, and crispy tofu are all great. Use all the sauces, because they are all awesome. Yes, the taro chips are worth it.
author: Angela C.

description: I would like to give this place 4 or 5 stars, but honestly it felt kind of dirty. My pho was pretty tasty, but I was still a bit uncomfortable with the feel of the place.
author: Kathy B.

description:
You get a lot of food for $9.50 (including tax). This place is like a chipotle in that they make it in front of you and you choose what you want to put inside.

Gave it 3 stars because despite all the different sauces you can use, it was lacking a bit of salt. 

Also the lemongrass pork wasn't as tasty as I thought it would be. I would still come here though because I like how fresh it is.
author: Alice C.

description:
I had the grilled chicken freshrolls. They pack a lot of meat and veggie filling inside, along with rice noodles. There's a little sauce station at the end of the counter where you can help yourself to a selection of sauces and water. The rolls were really fresh tasting and filling.

My only gripe is that the restaurant seating area is quite dirty. Sticky floors and tables and leftover food debris was everywhere. There was a member of staff cleaning this area but they were obviously not doing a good job. This did ruin my overall experience and got me to thinking about the cleanliness of the kitchen etc.

If I do return I will get the rolls to go and eat them outside.
author: Hannah H.

description:
The food is great just pity about the service!

For a production line of 10 people the queue is always ridiculous....always due to the staff seeming to have no clue of what they're doing despite it appearing to be a production line....seriously, how can this take sooooo long! 

This is not my first time here & this happens every time I'm here. Management take note: train your staff.
author: Nicole E.

description:
Context: needed a quick but non-greasy lunch option near the convention center

Ordered: 4 rolls (chicken, pork, beef, tofu) 

Service: pretty decent wait and staff speed did not change no matter how long the line got

Ambience: pretty good for a fast food place

Verdict: fresh Vietnamese rolls with amazingly strong rice wrapper that kept everything from falling out. Could have used more flavor in the rolls themselves but the multiple dipping sauces (hoisin, peanut, fish sauce, sweet chili) made up for the blandness. Worth the wait.
author: Jo S.

description: Delicious food!! Sauces were great and so were the taro chips! The bowl with the rice and tofu was perfect and filling. Great portions, very busy, not a lot of seating. Don't forget to check in and get 10% of your meal!!
author: Jenna L.

description:
A great spot for a quick Vietnamese lunch. There was a long queue when we arrived but it moved pretty quickly. I enjoyed the "Chipotle/Subway" style for ordering. I.e. choose your type, choose your protein, and choose your filling.

I got an order of the bowl with noodles and an order of the rolls. At first it didn't look like a lot of food, but it was! The bowl by itself was a good sized lunch. The food was really fresh, and the lemon pork was to die for! I only wished it would have been easier to mix the bowl together with the nice sauces.

It's definitely more of a fast food place. My only complaint was that the tables were sticky and the seating area in general wasn't very clean.
author: Philip B.

description: I love Freshroll............................................................................ The spring rolls (pork with the standard) are the best, and I can't stop eating them. I'll never get sick of them. I can eat them every meal, every day. I don't get any sauces because they're great on their own. Lines can get pretty crazy especially if there's a big conference at Moscone, but it's okay the spring rolls are worth the wait. The bowl and sandwich are both great as well.
author: Annie S.

description:
I'm beating myself up for not checking this place out sooner. My sister-in-law recommended it to me months ago, but the lines always deterred me from actually going. One day earlier this week, I felt patient to brave it, and I also had time to wait in line. I figured, if I didn't do it then, then when? This is also the reason I deducted a star in the review. 

Ordering was easy, but when you do, you must tell the first person who lays out the wrap what you want (crispy tofu, chicken, garlic shrimp), then you move over to the next person who actually puts the stuff in, and then the next person who rolls it. I was a virgin so I didn't know to roll down the line like that. 

You can a fried scallion, which is referred to as, "crispy goodness,"  to any of the rolls. You can also add extra shrimp to your order as well, which I did and it cost me another $4/$5 to my order. 

The rolls were definitely fresh and delicious! I went the next day again and was still raving about how yummy they were. This time, though, my friend ordered online and we were able to bypass the line and pick it up- prepaid and all.
author: Sharon B.

description:
Ah, Freshroll. My number one spot for a late lunch. It's hard to beat the noodle bowl with a generous helping of lemongrass pork, a heaping pile of fresh, raw veggies with a little drizzle of sweet chilli sauce for a incredibly delicious and fresh-tasting lunch. I always walk away from this place feeling *healthier* than when I entered, which is always a great feeling and hard to find at the greasy restaurants in this area.

The only warning I'd give is that the line is incredibly long because the service seems pretty inefficient. Be prepared to have to wait 10-20 minutes at peak lunch hour. Portions are large and prices are reasonable - check in on Yelp for 10% off!
author: Victor S.

description:
I wandered here because SoMA is a bit lacking of food options on the weekend. This place is an attempt at Chipotle-style Vietnamese food (hopefully without the E. coli), with slightly higher-than-Chipotle prices (around $9 for a meal). You can pick rolls, noodle bowl, or noodle soup and then your choice of meat, with some ability to customize what goes inside your meal. The food, however, is mediocre. It also feels like a very cheapened experience when your dish so obviously represents a simple permutation of different ingredients that you can choose.

Oddly enough, when I was there, there was a large group of Vietnamese tourists who seemed to be traveling with some tourism company - of all the Vietnamese restaurants in the city, WHY WOULD YOU BRING THEM TO HERE? I felt kind of embarrassed that this is how they got to experience America.
author: Sidney L.

description: Had lunch for first time there today (7/19/17).  High anticipation for what looked to be a fresh, tasty chicken sandwich quickly evaporated when I pulled a two-foot long hair out of my sandwich.  A quick glance at the girl who made the sandwich confirmed her hair wasn't in any kind of hairnet.   Grossest thing I've ever experienced at a meal.   You've been warned.
author: Mark H.

description:
A return visit for lunch. This busy little eating house is so consistent. The food is predictably good.

We both enjoyed the spring rolls - we had the shrimp, the pork and the chicken with lettuce, jalapeños, green onions and more .... delicious, substantial and very filling. A good lunch option - service is quick and the food is prepared as you watch. Good for a quick bite when you want a little something that is fresh and healthy. 

We will be back in due course.
author: Mick A.

description:
Freshroll is a great place in the Metreon/Moscone Convention Center area to get a quick and tasty lunch. The setup is analogous to a Chipotle. You can choose between 3 Vietnamese spring rolls, a noodle or rice bowl, a banh mi sandwich, or pho. Next, you choose your meat, veggies, and the sauces you want. 

I came with a friend last week while we were attending a conference. I ordered the spring rolls with the lemongrass pork and "the standard" (lettuce, bean sprouts, jalapenos, cilantro, cucumbers) set of vegetables as well as pickled carrots. As the name implies, all of the ingredients in my roll were fresh and very flavorful. The pork was tender and nicely seasoned. I opted for the peanut sauce to dip my spring rolls in. Three rolls was the perfect amount of food. I felt satisfied without being overly full. This is perfect for conferences, because you don't want to pass out from a food coma while listening to the afternoon talks. Overall, the food was tasty and the service was fast. I'd definitely recommend this place for lunch.
author: Ravi S.

description: Loved this place. Had three rollups with fresh veggies and spicy pork and they were awesome.  The plus was the choice of sauces - I tried sweet chili and also had a vietnamese vinaigrette which was great.  I also liked the lime soda.   It's not the cheapest option but it's really good. No wonder there is a line out the door at lunchtime.
author: David Z.

description:
We wanted a quick bite before seeing a movie.  After walking around the neighborhood we decided to try Freshroll 

We had the pork Freshroll which was good, but not great.

However the pho was very good. I had the standard toppings, minus jalapeños, with rare steak.  The chicken based broth was so flavorful, much better than the beef based broths I've had in San Mateo or Millbrae.  The broth tastes clean, yet flavorful, with complexity that is not just a salty taste.  My friend tried the Vietnamese iced coffee but said it was too sweet and would not order it again.

I would definitely order the pho again. The broth is really wonderful.
author: Joanna S.

description: It looks like a fast food joint but they are so slow.  I got a pho and they forgot to put the order in until I asked why people after me got theirs already.
author: L W.

description:
Not perfect, but hits the spot. It's fast food, so I don't expect an amazing meal. But every time I need a quick fix for fresh rolls or pho, I come here. It's not simply ok, but delicious. 

The rolls are delicious and usually overstuffed. This is a full meal and you will be stuffed. The standard fillings aren't my preference, but the make-your-own format means you can tailor your roll to your taste. I like more veggies and herbs in mine. Definitely go for the crunch, which provides a nice texture contrast. 

The pho is below average, but not bad. It has good flavor and meat. This isn't a dedicated pho joint so not going to knock them for it.
author: Yoeun P.

description: Came here with a group of about 12. It was ok a busy afternoon when there was also a conference happening across the street. I got the tofu sandwich. For the price, it was a good size. The bread was very tasty and the filling was generous. It was filling and tasty. My only complaint was that the water pitcher was always running out of water. If you check in you save 10% which I did.
author: Crys L.

description:
I had put Freshroll on my Bookmark list awhile back when I was perusing for options around where I work, so when my friend and I met up at Bloomingdales and saw that Turtle Tower is closed for renovation, we needed a fast option for something else close by.  I immediately thought of Freshroll, mostly because I had it in my mind to have Vietnamese food.

When we walked in, it was evident that this was probably going to be closer to a fusion experience rather than an authentic one.  Not really a big deal to me, think of what goes through your mind when you walk into a Chipotle for the first time after thinking you want an authentic burrito.  Speaking of Chipotle, the ordering system works very similar to that.  My process went as follows:

1) Pick your Style: Vermicelli noodle bowl
2) Pick your Protein: Lemongrass pork
3) Pick your Veggies: Bean sprouts, cucumbers, scallions
4) Pick your Sauces: Vietnamese Vinaigrette (aka nuoc cham)

It was all placed very nicely into the bowl and my friend got a Vietnamese Iced Coffee along with her Pork noodle bowl.  I love nuoc cham, especially full-flavored and less diluted by water nuoc cham.  Freshroll's version (and then calling it vinaigrette...really?) was mediocre and was watery with not too much flavor in the bottle.  What I did like about the bowl was the pork.  It had a really good flavor to it and they gave me a very generous serving. The veggies were also good, and at the end of the meal, I really thought that while it pales in comparison to somewhere like Bun Mee, for being around Westfield and City Target, this was a solid lunch spot.  I definitely think this is one of the better options around here, maybe after Super Duper and Tropisueno.  Anyway, check it out if you're around the area and are looking for something different.
author: Lisa I.

description: Although the Chicken Pho fell flat for me, the made-to-order Spring Rolls and variety of sauces for dunking are a good reason to return.
author: Amy C.

description: Great Vietnamese Food.  The lemongrass pork is delicious and the vegetables are fresh.  I tried the noodle bowl and couldn't stop eating till it was all gone.  Very good prices too.
author: Aaron S.

description:
2 words: Lemongrass pork. It's good in a sandwich, it's good in a roll and it's good in a bowl, and I generally don't even like pork. Overall, Freshroll is a solid choice for a quick lunch on a weekday. A meal is less than $10, it's somewhat healthy, and you have a lot of options to customize your order - what more could you want? 

Don't count on eating here though - there's only a few tables and they're always taken during lunch hours.
author: Melody Y.

description:
I absolutely love this place! My coworker suggested I come here one day when I was wanting to eat something healthy(ish), and now I'm hooked! I've been here twice with my boyfriend in the span of a week and I will definitely come again once I'm back in San Francisco.

Freshroll is like a Vietnamese Chipotle - limited variety, fast, and made to order. They have a choice of 4 items: pho, spring rolls, banh mi sandwich, and my favorite, the bowl. They all basically have the same stuff, just depends on how you want to eat it. I've tried the latter 3 and here are my suggestions:

-If you're looking for something hot and substantial, get the banh mi sandwich. My boyfriend loves this and refuses to get anything else because he thinks it's the best bang for your buck. Granted, it is the cheapest out of the 3. 
-If you want something a little more light and refreshing, but still has substance, get the bowl. I personally love the bowl because you can load it with veggies and the fish sauce adds such a nice flavor.
-I would stay away from the spring rolls. Don't get me wrong, they're still delicious, but for the price of 3 spring rolls, you can get the bowl which, in my opinion, has a much greater quantity. 

My only caveat with this place is that the line is super long if you come during lunch hours on a work day, but it moves fast enough and it's definitely worth the wait.
author: Betty W.

description:
This place is minimalistic (streamlined for the lunch rush I assume) but friendly.  Dropped by on a lazy shopping Sunday.

Freshrolls: 4 stars
I did mix-and-match pork and tofu here. Add your choice of veggies, Subway-style but you get pineapples, bell peppers, scallions, pickled carrots and turnips here. The sauces added the last half-star.

Pho Broth: 4.5 stars
This shit is delicious.

They've won me over.  I'd definitely come back.
author: Letitia L.

description: This place is awesome. I love spring rolls when I'm trying to go for a bit of a healthier meal. 3 rolls for $7, I usually do a combo of the chicken and pork. One word of advice: ADD THE CRISPY GOODNESS. It makes a world of a difference - nowhere near the infamous Brodard's but it definitely reminds me of it. I also love the variety of sauces they provide. 2 thumbs up!
author: Angela K.

description:
********************* 1122 *********************

      I kind of dig this place. While attending the SEMICON WEST conference, I stopped by here for the beef PHO, I was surprised how decent it was. The broth was clear, the noodle was right and the beef was good. Only thing I didn't care for is that they put the basil/bean sprouts inside the bowl, who does that? Well I guess it's a fast food place.

    I came back the second day for the pork spring rolls, it was very good. 

    The service was fast, all dishes were under $10, that's CHEAP EAT by the Moscone center, my consulting company was very happy with my receipts. Normally my work lunch should be around $75.

    Good food, authentic, cheap eat, convenient for Moscone Center attendees!  Will be back at the next conference or when I'm shopping around the area.
author: Manda Bear B.

description: Super surprised how much I liked this. I got the tofu and it was cooked well and enjoyable (not someone who ever eats tofu). I told the man to make it how he likes it and I ended up getting a pineapple and jalapeño mix that was way too good. Their sauces are delicious and make every bite even that much more tasty. Only in town visiting but I will definitely be back on my next visit up here from Orange County! :) two thumbs up loved it
author: Kalie K.

description:
Full disclosure: my first two experiences at Freshroll weren't that great, but the third time was the charm. 

First time around, I tried their banh mi sandwich and was very underwhelmed. Same goes for the bowl. The spring rolls, though... that's where they really excel. For a mere $10 (including tax, not tip), you get three rice paper-wrapped rolls with your choice of fixins and protein. I always get the crispy tofu (double tofu, if I can afford it), lettuce, bean sprouts, pickled vegetables, red bell peppers, and jalepenos. 

Critical California con: the avocado never looks fresh, so I skip it. 

This is probably the healthiest option that is close to my job, unless I'm in the mood for walking three blocks for a $13 build-your-own salad from Whole Foods (also a solid option, but too out-of-the-way for a 30 minute lunch break). Plant-based is the type of vegan I SHOULD be, but I more often than not catch myself eating Gardein fried "chicken" strips or other junk foods. Freshroll makes it super easy to eat something both delicious and nutritious. Most of the employees area really cool and they know about vegan options, which I really, genuinely, wholeheartedly appreciate.  

There's always a rather intimidating line at lunchtime on a weekday, so either go before or after the noon-time rush, or I guess order online, if you're in a hurry. I like watching my food being made in front of me, so I'll sometimes brave the ferocious queue and eat my lunch with a quickness. I guess in the end it's still fast food (wink wink, bad pun, ha ha ha). 

As far as sauces go, the peanut sauce is my fave, but I also dig the sweet and sour. If you are vegan or vegetarian, do not get the vinaigrette, as it contains seafood. 

I am a spring roll snob, and these pass the taste test. I still think my favorite spring rolls were the ones at The Plant Cafe, although I have not eaten those ones in quite some time. Maybe I will visit again sometime and see how they stack up to Freshroll. Until then, I will keep eating these and keep that "spring" in my step (bad pun number two, I'm on a *roll*). ;)
author: Brandi W.

description:
My favorite lunch during work! I pay about 10.50 for the 3 rolls with teriyaki chicken and "the standard" - pickled carrots, cilantro, noodles, cucumbers, fried shallots, jalapeños and I add avocado!

The staff is also nice and there's places to sit and look out the window.
author: Miranda S.

description:
3.5 rating for Freshroll, which reminds me of Chipotle.  Pretty much you get in line and choose to have your food served as 3 spring rolls, a bahn mi, or in a bowl.  I opt for the 3 Freshrolls option and then chose my protein fillings.  Afterward, I got to choose what type of veggies went into my rolls (note, they have pineapple as an option, which is very unique) and then I pay for my food.  

 tried this place out last night and really liked their garlic shrimp and lemongrass pork spring rolls.  I also ordered the crispy tofu and their chicken, but didn't enjoy them very much.  

This place is pricy for spring rolls (nearly $3/roll), but they do boast fresh and organic ingredients.  If you want to have a crispy scallion roll in your spring roll, you gotta cough up an additional 75 cents.  Also, if you order their bowl option, you can pay $1.50 more for a small side of chicken broth.  I was willing to pay for it, but they ran out by the time I got there.  SADNESS.

I'd come here again, but next time I will pass on the chicken and tofu.  I'd rather pay the extra money for the garlic shrimps.  Those were quite good.
author: May W.

description: This place is pretty unique for an east coast guy.  The rolls were good and the place had a good amount of variety for your rolls.  It gets crowded during lunch time but it is worth the wait.  I liked the idea of eating these rolls for lunch.  I got three roll 2 chicken and one shrimp.  I preferred the chicken roll.  I probably needed 4 or 5 rolls because I got hungry 2 hours later.  I would come here again in a heart beat.  It is a little hard to find a table during lunch time because they are so crowded.  The service was great.  Even though they were very busy everyone behind the counter worked will to get the rolls made and were polite throughout the whole process.
author: Abbas B.

description: This was terrible pho... no flavor, the music is too Loud and making it difficult to enjoy a meal.
author: David V.

description: It's OK, the vermicelli noodles were actually a bit overcooked and I think it's rather overpriced for what you get, but it's usually quick and decent.  Wish they had fish sauce and some sambal instead of Siracha, just kinda basic for the price tag.
author: Kevin L.

description:
I can tell these Chipotle-style Asian fast-food operations are starting to proliferate because the budget-conscious, assembly-line approach works for subs and burritos - so why not noodle bowls and rice paper rolls? By coincidence, I tried the nearby Bamboo Asia the other week, and that takes the same concept but goes for a contrived triple play by covering India, Japan, and Thailand. Freshroll wisely doesn't attempt a far-flung tour of the Far East. Instead, they focus strictly on Vietnam and consequently doesn't suffer from the Jack-in-the-Box syndrome of spreading itself too thin across a continent.

I've been twice now - the first time by chance on their opening day, the second a couple of weeks later to see if some of the preparation jitters by the neophyte staff were ironed out. I think it's decent fare, nothing all that extraordinary and nothing that offensive, right in the middle. It's pretty easy to grasp what they're doing here once you study the menu once. You choose one of seven fillings and/or toppings (interestingly, none of them beef) - two variations on grilled chicken, another two using pork, one combo pork and chicken, one shrimp only, and one veggie option with tofu.

Then you decide the vessel upon which you want them to place your ingredients - a roll trio, a super-roll, a vermicelli noodle bowl, a rice bowl, or a lettuce bowl. I went with one of the chicken choices in a lettuce bowl both times since I'm trying to watch my carb intake. I thought the grilled chicken in the Californian ($8.45) on my first visit was not as good as it was in the 49er ($7.65) on my second visit. I think the slight kick of the jalapeno and the twang of the pickled veggies were a better match than the blandness of the avocado (see photo). I also noticed an improvement in the execution on my second visit wherein the chicken was more effectively mixed with the lettuce versus simply putting the poultry on top.

This enhancement prevented a potential mess on the counter since you minimize the manual mixing needed to produce a truly integrated bowl. At the same time, I still thought the lettuce bowls were a little too light on all the secondary ingredients mentioned in the description and the sauces a bit on the watery side. Interestingly, unlike Bamboo Asia, the bánh mìs and pho noodle bowls listed on the menu are handled separately from the assembly line. They also offer sides, extras and Vietnamese iced coffee to keep it as real as they can. Given the owner's enthusiasm in responding to customer feedback on Yelp, I look forward to seeing continued improvements in this most welcome establishment.

FOOD - 3 stars...decent production-line Vietnamese fast-food, fresher than you would expect
AMBIANCE - 3.5 stars...clean and streamlined (see photo)
SERVICE - 3 stars..amiable enough though a bit on automatic pilot
TOTAL - 3 stars...solid effort worth checking out over time
author: Ed U.

description:
If ur going to AMC...  ::: go HERE b4:

It's ur place to stop so you don't spend $50 on popcorn and candy at the theatre food counter.

 Amazing rolls. 

In order : tofu, lemon grass pork, chicken. The staff is sOOOOOO friendly. 

Insider note: use ALLLL the sauces!!!!
author: James W.

description: Fresh and flavorful ingredients, simple selection menu and excellent service. I really enjoyed it. Would come back again for a quick snack.
author: Juriy Z.

description:
Very delicious! I came here super hungry one night and got the steak pho, fresh -wrapped spring rolls (2 lemon grass pork and 1 chicken - they let you mixed and match) and a limeade. Yum yum!

For the pho, I recommend eating spreading out the beef as soon as you get it. I didn't spread out all the meat, and left some in lumps that the broth wasn't hot enough to cook through. Overall, the meat was tender, and the broth was flavorful. 

I like that you get to pick your filling for the Vietnamese spring rolls. These taste great a s leftover the next day too. What I like is that there are a variety of dipping sauces you can pick from. Try one, or try them all! I like the peanut sauce and the Vietnamese vinaigrette best. 

Will definitely come back again.
author: Cynthia X.

description:
My review is on their Spring Rolls. :D It's the only thing I tried, but they also have Banh Mi (Vietnamese Sandwiches) Salad,  and Noodle bowls (bun thit nuong). I believe you also have the option of rice if you didn't want noodles. 

I will say this is a modern take on traditional Vietnamese food. Of all the asian rolls you can think of- Chinese eggrolls, Filipino lumpias, the Vietnamese spring roll is the healthiest. Fact. :D

The decor is very "fresh and simple." Nothing over the top, and these days, simplicity is severely underrated. There is a big open kitchen and you can see people working and prepping in the back. It's also SUPER CLEAN and spacious. 

Onto food. I ordered the 3 freshrolls. You had options on protein- grilled pork, chicken, and tofu. I picked one of each. Then you get to pick your veggies- I had pineapple, lettuce, pickled veggies, and bean sprouts. They recommended the crispy stick, and that was an awesome texture to the roll. And lastly, your sauces. You had 4 options - the peanut sauce sweet and spicy chilli, citrus gingers, and the traditional Vietnamese vinaigrette.  The roll is actually pretty big, so the prices are pretty decent.

I really enjoyed my rolls. It was fresh, clean, and delicious! I also had their Vietnamese limade, and I have to say, of all lemonades made in the world, the Vietnamese have it down to perfection.

I would recommend everyone to come here. The staff is friendly, knowledgeable, and STILL LEARNING!. Only downside is that they might be slow, but they are a new business, so give them a fighting chance.
author: Leena N.

description: This was a great, fast lunch while running around the Yerba Buena/ SfMOMA/ Moscone Center area. Tasty, fun, and crunchy.   Everything was fresh and made to order. Sauces were delicious and prepared in individual containers so that the peanuts were segregated. Great for my allergy.   The standard "three roll" combo was a lot of food for lunch, and you won't go hungry.
author: Meredith S.

description: Was looking for a quick dinner in an area where good dinner options are sparse. We stumbled upon this place, my guests got bowls and I got the freshrolls. The food was fresh, tasty, and simple. The sauces are labeled vegan, gluten free, etc. and even the tofu was delicious. I'm sad I don't live closer to this place! Check it out.
author: Jay H.

description:
If you come after 12:15 order online for pickup.  The line gets out the door long and it will take forever and a day.  One would think the line would move fast since it's "Chipotle" style but fact is, it moves slow.  

I like the concept of this, their ingredients are fresh but why don't they offer beef on their spring rolls and only for pho?!?!

Don't come here expecting too much, their food may be "fresh" but it is nowhere near authentic.  After eating the food here several times, I couldn't take it anymore and had to hit up my local Viet restaurant for some authentic rolls.  

There's a sauce station and sriracha if you ask for it.  It's overpriced for what it is but healthy and convenient.
author: Erica C.

description: YUMMY! And on.e of the women there helped me above and beyond. She wrote down what I could order that was gluten free and vegan. When I came back a couple weeks later she remembered me and was so sweet. It will be a regular spot for me
author: Kyra B.

description:
I was shocked that this place was good. I was shooting for "good enough", really. I was headed to the neurogaming conference at Metreon (nerd alert), and needed something to stave off my hunger for a bit.

Walked by this place, one of my last three options before arrival, and thought that a banh mi (Vietnamese sub) sounded good. And they're hard to really mess up too badly.

And mess it up they didn't! The sub was on excellent bread, crunchy and toasty and delicious. The pork was savory and perfectly seasoned. The vegetables, even the cilantro, fresh. It was seriously one of the top five I've had, and I've had a lot.

Taro chips were a delightful side dish as well. 

Diet Coke was... um... Diet Cokey. Not really a whole lot to say.

Inexpensive(ish) and shockingly good. Just a hidden gem that looks like it'd be "adequate" and chain-like... but... dayum!
author: Sean B.

description:
Got my lunch from Freshroll today. I got the bowl with white rice, chicken, lettuce, carrots, bean sprouts, and the chili sauce. I want to try the peanut sauce next time. I was quite impressed with the portion size. It was very filling (about as much as a Chipotle burrito bowl) and under $10.

The line is usually long (I went close to 1pm and there were still about a dozen people in front of me), but it goes by fairly quickly. This place is a two minute walk from my office, so I'll definitely be coming back!
author: China W.

description: I don't even know what to say. You would be better off taking $12 and wiping your ass with it than buying a bowl of pho here. No flavor and where is the "steak" I paid for? Shame on you Freshroll.
author: Steve B.

description:
Try the 3 rolls with chicken and the standard toppings, and Grandma's peanut sauce with a swirl of Sriracha. A refreshing snack or meal (surprisingly filling!)

The only downside is they have skimped on the protein lately.
author: Kieu T.

description:
This place serves up a new way to eat a classic Vietnamese dish. 

PRICE
It's a bit steep considering that you can get the same thing in San Jose in a Vietnamese restaurant for half of the price, but then again it's SF.

ENVIRONMENT 
They have shared tables with a standard order as you go approach similar to Chipotle.

SERVICE
Don't expect the service to be fast. It's slow; especially during lunch hour. You could wait up to 30 minutes on line.

FOOD
The standard bowl is pretty good and you get a 10% discount if you check in on Yelp and show the cashier. You can opt to pick your own five toppings as well, but you get 7 with the standard.
author: Eric E.

description:
I order wraps with pork and tofu. pretty good. Not much special. Meats not much flavorful,  but fresh with lots of vegi and tasty sauce. Yes ,I would stop by to get light lunch if I am around. 

Chips are no no. Dry, no flavor, hard.  I would not order it.
author: Sua Y.

description:
Catered lunch from here and it was surprisingly good. 
The noodle is meant to be eaten cold, and goes very well with the vietnamese vinaigrette (I suspect it is a combination of fish sauce ++ )

The grilled chicken was fragrant and tender. The lemongrass pork was slightly tough, dry and chewy, but it was still fragrant.

For the more adventurous, try the ginger sauce (goes well with chicken), peanut sauce and chilli sauce.
author: Christina N.

description:
Freshrolls is like Chipotle of Vietnamese food in so many ways. As it turns out, it is 2 doors down from Chipotle, but unlike their neighbor, the spring roll assembly process is inefficient and slow, so expect a 20+ minute wait if the line reaches the door.

The idea is that they serve bowls (rice, noodles or salad) and spring rolls with your choice of toppings. The variety of veggie toppings is impressive, and surprise surprise, very fresh. They skimped on the proteins, and the proteins were average (think Sanraku from the food court.. tasty but you know what you're getting into when you order "Bourbon Chicken"). Chicken and pork a tad bit dry, shrimp was probably my favorite. Can't go wrong either way. 

Premium add-ons: Avocado, bacon, fried eggroll wrappers. 

To be honest, I love Chipotle's cilantro lime rice and corn salsa, and I'm not going to lie, I also love my Americanized Vietnamese spring rolls, so 4 stars for cheap, fresh, Americanized Vietnamese spring rolls.

Pro-Tip: Vietnamese iced coffee is pre-mixed so you can't lower the sweetness level.
author: Jess C.

description: Quick and super close to the convention center. Amazing to have fresh veggies after so many days of heavy travel food.
author: Stephanie s.

description:
Freshroll is one of the usuals in my lunch rotation, and it's super fresh (see what I did there) every time. I've heard mixed opinions on their sandwiches and rolls, but the noodle bowls are legit. Try the Crispy Goodness too! They're like thin crispy egg rolls with scallions inside. Freshroll also has pho if you go after 3pm on weekdays, but it's available all day on the weekends.

Pro-tip: the lunch lines can be long so order ahead through their website, and then head out 15-20 minutes after you order to pick it up!
author: Nikhil S.

description:
Wow, can I just say... Their food tastes like homemade. My boyfriend and I ordered 3 garlic shrimp spring rolls and two bowls of chicken pho. There sauces for the spring rolls was very rich and flavorful. I especially like the peanut sauce.

Their pho broth was very good, it tasted like home to me back in Sacramento! I enjoyed every bite and it was the perfect portion too.

I will come back!
author: Ritney N.

description:
Their website makes ordering lunch so convenient. Freshroll is often frequented by so many lunch-goers that the line is out the door. I'd recommend creating an account and ordering your lunch ~30min. in advance. You can customize your order as you see fit. 

I recommend the tofu rolls with fresh tofu (instead of fried). I especially like dipping them in the sweet and sour chili sauce. YUM.

My office ordered a copious amount of rolls (tofu/chicken/pork/fish) and sandwiches from this location and they did a great job of preparing such a large order with no mistakes. Everyone was happy because the food was good but didn't leave you feeling heavy.
author: Ruth R.

description:
When I'm eating lunch in SF I don't have a lot of time to wait in lines or wait for service so I really like that I have an option like Freshroll where it's an order-at-the-counter kind of set up that is simple, filling, and tastes good. You basically can choose to get freshrolls (kind of like a spring roll), a sandwich, or a bowl set up. Then you pick meats, veggies, add-ons like avocado or crunchy bacon, and a sauce. My meal was less than $10 and I was in and out of there in about 40 minutes total.

There isn't a ton of seating, but most people seem to take their food to go so it was a huge issue. However, I don't think it'd be great for groups. 

Bonus: they have online ordering so take advantage of that and have an even smaller wait time.
author: Tiffany N.

description:
The unofficial Chipotle of Vietnamese food. You order the vessel in which you'd like to eat: summer roll, banh mi, bowl with rice, noodles or salad. Then go down the assembly line and add on protein and veggies. Everything was solid. It was quick and efficient, with a variety of very fresh ingredients. 

I got the salad bowl with chicken and the works which included and not limited to carrots, cukes, sprouts, peppers etc... I wish they added the hot sauce/dressing for it instead of me going and just throwing some random ones on. I went with a peanut/spicy sweet/jalapeno vinegarette combo and overall it wasn't the best mix of flavors. Although the ingredients are super fresh, this overall salad was pretty tasteless. 

Those summer rolls looked bangin', so I'd say it's safe to say stick with those, they seem to be their speciality of the house!

A quick, easy, healthy and reliable lunch ain't such a bad thing!
author: Stephanie Y.

description: Probably the worst Chicken Pho (Pho Ga) I have had in the city. Mediocre broth, not great chicken. I had to dump in a bunch of Sriracha to make it palatable. Not expensive, but not worth the price. Try Tin Vietnamese instead - it's just down the road.
author: Vaibhav M.

description: So they call this place the chipotle of Vietnamese food. I think this place has a lot of potential. Too bad the name is so generic and not creative at all. But the food was really good. As a lover of Vietnamese food, I found the concept of this Vietnamese fast food very smart. I had the 3 rolls. Very filling and satisfying. The four sauces they offered were amazing as well. It was a satisfying dinner for only 10 bucks. I'm a fan!
author: Nin A.

description:
Huge fan of this place. their sandwiches and rolls are delicious. They're light and stuffed. 

BONUS**** Their sandwiches bread is SOFT!!! I repeat SOFT! that never happens! That won my heart over.
author: Pj A.

description:
Skip Chipotle and stroll down to Freshroll! Instead of burritos, burrito bowls, and tacos, you can purchase fresh spring rolls, rice/vermicelli bowls, and sandwiches. Doesn't that sound more exciting and healthy? OK, I might be a bit biased since I'm not a huge fan of Mexican food but even if you are, you should give Freshroll a try!

How you order:
- Pick a bowl, sandwich, 3 rolls, or pho
- Choose your protein: lemongrass pork, grilled chicken, garlic shrimp, steak, or tofu
- Next comes the toppings (too many to list)
- Any add-ons: Crispy Goodness, bacon, avocado
- Then the sauce: peanut, ginger, sweet and sour chili, or Vietnamese vinaigrette 

The food at Freshroll is light and refreshing. The line can be crazy, but it moves rather quickly. I ordered the lemongrass pork vermicelli bowl and it was a great blend of veggies, meat, and noodles. Although they could have been more generous with the pork. Plus, the meat was dry, but can't complain. This IS Vietnamese fast food. I do appreciate the numerous toppings that they offer. My favorites are the pineapple and pickled vegetables. Their sauces are fantastic! I know everyone loves peanut sauce by default (unless you're allergic) but be adventurous and try the tangy citrus ginger. It's a zesty party in your mouth! 

I had their lychee iced tea which needed a lot more lychee flavor. However, I think Freshroll is a solid spot for lunch as it is affordable and healthy!
author: Judy H.

description: This modern Vietnamese spot is right next to the Metreon in downtown SF. The menu is kind of chaotic in the store. There is so much going on. I got a sandwich with lemongrass pork..it was pretty good. Freshly made right in front of you. It would be nice to have a noodle soup sometime. I'd come back if I was around there.
author: Denise C.

description:
Bowl w lemon grass pork was awesome. This place is cheap and the food is very fresh. Lines are long so plan to wait for around 20 minutes during peak lunch hours. 

Would definitely come back for more.
author: Brian L.

description: I LOVE freshroll. I've gone to the location as well as ordered from caviar and it is always delicious. It's nice to have a fresh, quick option that can be customized to your liking. The sauces are all delicious and take any of the menu options to the next level. My go-to is the noodle bowl with the pork and all the veggies.
author: Kelsey O.

description:
FOOD- It's ok. Maybe because I'm around Little Saigon in SoCal, so my standard for solid Viet food is higher. I could've used way more bean sprouts and basil (even though I asked for more basil already). It still didn't seem like nearly enough compared to the quantity given at traditional Viet restaurants. The cut of the steak meat for their pho seems more Americanized; however, it is pleasantly undercooked, tender, and oh so juicy. 

COST- Everything is the same price point, just under $9. To me, this doesn't really make sense since 3 rolls for $9 seems pricey and not filling. My friend thought the same, so she ordered a rice salad bowl while I ordered a pho noodle soup bowl. Food for thought, more bang for your buck. 

SERVICE- Self-serve rather than waiter. You pay at the front and get your own food, utensils, and water. 

Seems like a good option if you're looking for Viet food to-go.
author: Phoebe C.

description:
What a fantasticky lunch idea! We headed for an early lunch and i wasn't exactly hungry. As I was standing in a line, reading the menu hunger came to me. From 3 types of meal, I chose the rolls with shrimp and avocado. For sides, I added all the vegetables accept pineapple and jalapeños.
You can choose each roll to be different but my combination was sooo good, I really wanted all 3 of them to be the same.

The best part of this experience were definitely the sources. I tried all 4 of them and preferred the peanut butter one. With lychee tea, it was a perfect light lunch.

Seating is a bit tricky. We managed to get there early enough but after 12, I would take it to go!
author: Michaela P.

description:
"Vietpotle?" Yes indeed!

Bright, sparkling shop that serves rolls, bowls (rice, noodle, or salad), and sandwiches, with customizable proteins (pork, chicken, shrimp, tofu) and your choice of veggies. Generally fast, courteous service, and a super refreshing, tasty meal. Score!
author: Vincent L.

description:
Overall: Not satsifactory

Food: Portion was small. I got the rolls (pork, chicken, tofu). They literally put 2 strands of noodles onto to roll and 5 pieces of meat, 2 pieces of tofu. Then wrapped a whole lot of lettuce. I also got a side of taro chips, yes, they were interesting. Hard and greasy. My coworker got the bowl and said it was bland, nothing but plain noodles. 

Service: Slow, the lines wrap around the counter like if you're ordering subway. You see what they put in.  You won't be pleased with the stuff they put in your food. Can't imagine how they do business here. You leave this place still hungry!
author: Stephanie Y.

description:
I was a little skeptical when I was told we were going to 'the Chipotle of Vietnamese food', especially when my hometown has a large Vietnamese population and proves it in the restaurant stakes.

Freshroll's menu consists of westernized Vietnamese dishes like rolls, soups, rice paper rolls and more. You get to opt in or out on a lot of the ingredients to create your ideal dish. 

I was pleasantly surprised with my meal, yes it's a chain and queuing up in the line is like rubbing salt into the chain wound, but the food is fresh, tasty and plentiful in serving size. A great healthy work-day lunch.

You must try the peanut sauce!
author: Laura D.

description:
Supa dupa fresh rolls!   3.5 stars!!

This place isn't authentic vietnamnese food but it's a quick healthy lunch option. From their design aesthetic to the people that work in the kitchen you can obviously tell it's a modern twist to vietnamnese food giving you the option to customize. Service was pretty good and fast. It was around 12pm when I went in and the line was short and was fast. 

Love their fresh rolls: $7.95 for 3 big rolls. Super fresh. Create your own. You can choose from Shrimp, Pork, Beef and Tofu and also choose the vegetables you want in them.

Pho: $8.95 The soup was very bland. I tried it a couple of times hoping they just screwed up the first time but it's bland. :(

Great place to get a quick bite but if you have time to sit and have a meal i suggest to go to more yummy places close by like Miss saigon (on 6th and mission).

Will def come again! Yummy fresh rolls!!!
author: Jennie C.

description: I have irrational cravings for vietnamese spring rolls.  The weirdest craving ever, I know. But this place fulfills that craving. You can choose the fillings and there's an array of different sauces to drench your spring roll in.  This place is like the fast food place for vietnamese spring rolls.  Nothing gourmet, but fast, easy, and healthy.
author: Jenny C.

description:
Fresh. Custom. Healthy. What else can you ask for?

I personalized my fresh rolls with crispy tofu, lettuce, bean sprouts, cilantro, cucumbers, carrots, and pickled veggies.

Best of all, $7.95 for a super filling and super healthy lunch (or dinner). Can't beat that.

P.S. Order ahead online and pick-up in a jiffy!
author: Mansi A.

description:
Always a long line and fills you up at a good price might have gotten sick from
It once but not sure
author: Laura G.

description:
I kind of want to give this place two stars but I will play it nice! My friend and I were totally craving pho and came across all the stars this place had. The service was very so-so and the food was less than what I thought - considering my fellow yelpers reviews!
